title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to eligible entities for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative fuel vehicles, energy efficiency standards for public buildings, and participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs. The eligible entities can receive grants for clean energy initiatives such as using alternative fuel vehicles, increasing energy efficiency in public buildings, participating in greenhouse gas reduction programs, facilitating on-bill financing for energy improvements, and providing state tax incentives for clean energy components. The eligible entities can receive grants for clean energy initiatives such as participating in regional greenhouse gas reduction programs, facilitating on-bill financing for energy efficiency improvements, providing state tax incentives for clean energy components, offering innovative financing mechanisms for clean energy technologies, implementing best management practices for public utility commissions, and improving grid technology. To be eligible for a grant under this section, eligible entities must partner with private sector and non-governmental organizations to implement innovative financing mechanisms, best management practices for public utility commissions, grid technology improvements, and carbon efficiency standards. To be eligible for a grant under this section, eligible entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application. The Secretary will determine which entities receive awards. To be eligible for a grant, partners must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application. The Secretary will determine grant recipients based on the application information and criteria established by regulation. Grant funds must be used as specified. The Secretary will determine grant recipients based on application information and criteria established by regulation. Grant funds must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary. Regulations will be issued to establish criteria for grants under this section. Grant funds provided under this section must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary will issue regulations to establish criteria for grants, including eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing and ranking applications. The Secretary will issue regulations to establish criteria for grants under this section, including eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing and ranking applications, taking into account regional disparities in energy production and clean energy resource potential. The Secretary will consider regional disparities in energy production and clean energy potential when awarding grants under this Act. An explanation of the evaluation criteria will be published in the Federal Register. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic oil, gas, or primary products. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include oil related qualified production activities for major integrated oil companies. This is a conforming amendment to deny deduction for income from domestic oil, gas, or primary products. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include oil related qualified production activities for major integrated oil companies, with a conforming amendment to deny deduction for income from domestic oil, gas, or primary products. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010.
